metadata.description: Complete website content for Canadian Amyloidosis Society

hero.subtitle: Advancing evidence-based amyloidosis care through clinical excellence, professional collaboration, and structured knowledge sharing.

welcome.subtitle: Your trusted partner in amyloidosis care, connecting patients, families, and healthcare professionals across Canada.
welcome.description: We are dedicated to improving the lives of those affected by amyloidosis through education, support, and advocacy. Our comprehensive platform provides essential resources, connects you with specialized care, and builds a supportive community for patients and families nationwide.
welcome.missionText: To accelerate awareness, improve diagnosis, and enhance care for amyloidosis patients across Canada through education, advocacy, and community support.
welcome.visionText: A future where every Canadian affected by amyloidosis receives timely diagnosis, optimal treatment, and comprehensive support.

aboutAmyloidosis.subtitle: Amyloidosis is a rare disease with life-altering consequences—but early detection can dramatically improve outcomes. The Canadian Amyloidosis Society is building a trusted national hub for clinicians, researchers, and families seeking answers.
aboutAmyloidosis.description: Amyloidosis is a rare but serious condition where misfolded proteins (amyloid) accumulate in organs and tissues throughout the body. Understanding the different types, recognizing early symptoms, and accessing specialized care are crucial for managing this condition effectively.

earlyDetection.title: Early Detection
earlyDetection.subtitle: Saves Lives
earlyDetection.description: Amyloidosis is often misdiagnosed or diagnosed late because its symptoms mimic other conditions. Early recognition and proper testing are crucial for better patient outcomes.
earlyDetection.subdescription: Our directory connects patients with specialized centers and healthcare providers experienced in diagnosing and treating amyloidosis across Canada.

al.name: AL Amyloidosis
al.description: Most common form, affects heart, kidneys, liver, and nervous system

hereditary.name: Hereditary
hereditary.description: Genetic forms including TTR, fibrinogen, and lysozyme

stats.diagnosisTimeDesc: Many patients see multiple doctors before receiving proper diagnosis
stats.canadiansAffectedDesc: Estimated number of people living with amyloidosis in Canada

hero.subtitle: Learn the signs, understand the types, and take action early.
hero.description: Amyloidosis is a rare but serious disease where misfolded proteins accumulate in organs. Early detection and appropriate treatment can significantly improve outcomes.

pathophysiology.title: Pathophysiology
pathophysiology.description: Amyloidosis occurs when proteins misfold and accumulate in tissues.

aboutAmyloidosis.warningSignsSubtitle: Early symptoms that require medical attention.
aboutAmyloidosis.disclaimerText: This information is intended for healthcare professionals and educational purposes. It does not replace professional medical advice.

resources.question: How can I access clinical resources?
resources.answer: Healthcare professionals can access our clinical resources through the Resources section. Some materials require registration to ensure appropriate use in clinical settings.

membership.question: Is there a membership fee for CAS?
membership.answer: CAS membership is free for all healthcare professionals and researchers. Patient and family access to support resources is also provided at no cost.

support.question: Do you provide direct patient care?
support.answer: CAS does not provide direct patient care. We connect patients with specialized healthcare providers and provide educational resources to support informed healthcare decisions.

collaboration.question: How can my organization partner with CAS?
collaboration.answer: We welcome partnerships with healthcare institutions, research organizations, and professional societies. Contact us at professionals@canadianamyloidosis.ca to discuss collaboration opportunities.

resourcesContribute.question: Can I contribute clinical resources to CAS?
resourcesContribute.answer: Yes! We encourage healthcare professionals to share evidence-based resources. All submissions undergo peer review to ensure clinical accuracy and relevance.

updates.question: How do I stay updated on CAS activities?
updates.answer: Join our newsletter, follow our social media channels, or register for our professional network to receive regular updates on research, resources, and events.

contact.emergencyNote: For medical emergencies, please contact your healthcare provider or call 911

hero.subtitle: Faire progresser les soins d'amylose fondés sur des preuves grâce à l'excellence clinique, la collaboration professionnelle et le partage structuré des connaissances.

welcome.subtitle: Votre partenaire de confiance en soins d'amylose, connectant patients, familles et professionnels de la santé à travers le Canada.
welcome.description: Nous nous consacrons à améliorer la vie de ceux touchés par l'amylose par l'éducation, le soutien et l'advocacy. Notre plateforme complète fournit des ressources essentielles, vous connecte avec des soins spécialisés et construit une communauté de soutien pour les patients et familles à travers le pays.
welcome.missionText: Accélérer la sensibilisation, améliorer le diagnostic et optimiser les soins pour les patients atteints d'amylose à travers le Canada par l'éducation, l'advocacy et le soutien communautaire.
welcome.visionText: Un avenir où chaque Canadien touché par l'amylose reçoit un diagnostic précoce, un traitement optimal et un soutien complet.
welcome.exploreResources: En savoir plus sur notre travail

aboutAmyloidosis.subtitle: L'amylose est une maladie rare aux conséquences qui changent la vie—mais une détection précoce peut considérablement améliorer les résultats. La Société Canadienne d'Amylose construit un hub national de confiance pour les cliniciens, chercheurs et familles cherchant des réponses.
aboutAmyloidosis.description: L'amylose est une condition rare mais sérieuse où des protéines mal repliées (amyloïde) s'accumulent dans les organes et tissus à travers le corps. Comprendre les différents types, reconnaître les symptômes précoces et accéder aux soins spécialisés sont cruciaux pour gérer cette condition efficacement.

earlyDetection.title: Détection Précoce
earlyDetection.subtitle: Sauve des Vies
earlyDetection.description: L'amylose est souvent mal diagnostiquée ou diagnostiquée tardivement car ses symptômes imitent d'autres conditions. La reconnaissance précoce et les tests appropriés sont cruciaux pour de meilleurs résultats patients.
earlyDetection.subdescription: Notre répertoire connecte les patients avec des centres spécialisés et des fournisseurs de soins de santé expérimentés dans le diagnostic et le traitement de l'amylose à travers le Canada.

al.name: Amylose AL
al.description: Forme la plus commune, affecte le cœur, les reins, le foie et le système nerveux

hereditary.name: Héréditaire
hereditary.description: Formes génétiques incluant TTR, fibrinogène et lysozyme

stats.diagnosisTimeDesc: Beaucoup de patients voient plusieurs médecins avant de recevoir un diagnostic approprié
stats.canadiansAffectedDesc: Nombre estimé de personnes vivant avec l'amylose au Canada

hero.subtitle: Apprenez les signes, comprenez les types et agissez rapidement.
hero.description: L'amylose est une maladie rare mais grave où les protéines mal repliées s'accumulent dans les organes. La détection précoce et le traitement approprié peuvent considérablement améliorer les résultats.

pathophysiology.title: Pathophysiologie
pathophysiology.description: L'amylose survient quand les protéines se replient incorrectement et s'accumulent dans les tissus.

aboutAmyloidosis.warningSignsSubtitle: Symptômes précoces qui nécessitent une attention médicale.
aboutAmyloidosis.disclaimerText: Ces informations sont destinées aux professionnels de la santé et à des fins éducatives. Elles ne remplacent pas les conseils médicaux professionnels.
aboutAmyloidosis.emergencyText: Pour les urgences médicales, appelez le 911
aboutAmyloidosis.learnMoreAboutTypes: En savoir plus sur les types

mission.title: Connecting Healthcare Professionals
mission.description: The Canadian Amyloidosis Network (CANN) is a collaborative initiative that brings together healthcare professionals, researchers, and institutions across Canada to improve amyloidosis care and research.
keyPoints: Knowledge sharing and best practice development
Collaborative research initiatives and clinical trials

objectives.description: Facilitate collaborative research projects and clinical trials to advance understanding and treatment options.

objectives.description: Develop healthcare professional capacity through training, education, and knowledge exchange programs.

objectives.title: Improve Outcomes
objectives.description: Create measurable improvements in patient outcomes through coordinated care and research efforts.

al.title: AL Amyloidosis
al.subtitle: Light Chain Amyloidosis
al.description: Caused by abnormal plasma cells producing light chains that form amyloid. Often diagnosed after age 50; affects both men and women. Related to multiple myeloma (10-15% overlap).
symptoms: Skin changes (bruising, purple patches around eyes)
treatment: Supportive care to manage symptoms and organ function

treatmentCenters.name: CHUM - Centre hospitalier de l'Université de Montréal
Clinical Trial: Daratumumab in AL Amyloidosis

attr.title: ATTR Amyloidosis
attr.subtitle: Transthyretin Amyloidosis
attr.description: ATTR amyloidosis has two forms: Hereditary (hATTR) with over 120 TTR mutations known, and Wild-type (ATTRwt) which is non-inherited, develops with age, and primarily affects men over 60.
treatment: Supportive care for symptoms and organ protection

aa.title: AA Amyloidosis
aa.subtitle: Secondary Amyloidosis
aa.description: AA amyloidosis is caused by chronic inflammatory conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, or chronic infections.
diagnosis: Congo red staining of tissue biopsy

alect2.title: ALect2 Amyloidosis
alect2.subtitle: Leukocyte chemotactic factor 2 Amyloidosis
alect2.description: ALect2 amyloidosis is more common in Mexican, Punjabi, Native American, and Middle Eastern populations. Often underdiagnosed and mainly affects kidneys.
keyFeatures: More common in specific ethnic populations
diagnosis: Kidney biopsy with Congo red staining

other.title: Other Amyloidosis Types
other.subtitle: AA, ALECT2, Dialysis-related, and Rare Forms
other.description: Beyond AL and ATTR, several other forms of amyloidosis exist, each with unique characteristics, causes, and treatment approaches.

aa.name: AA (Secondary) Amyloidosis
aa.description: Caused by chronic inflammatory conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, or chronic infections.

localized.name: Localized Amyloidosis
localized.description: Amyloid deposits that remain confined to specific organs or tissues without systemic involvement.

dialysisRelated.name: Dialysis-related Amyloidosis
dialysisRelated.description: Develops in patients on long-term dialysis due to accumulation of β2-microglobulin protein.

rareVariants.name: Rare Variant Presentations
forms: ALECT2: More common in Mexican, Punjabi, Native American, Middle Eastern descent
Aβ2M: Seen in long-term dialysis patients, affects bones and joints

treatmentApproaches: AA: Treat underlying disease to reduce SAA protein
ALECT2: Often underdiagnosed, mainly affects kidneys
Aβ2M: Becoming rarer due to improved dialysis techniques
Supportive care and research ongoing for most types

national.name: Transthyretin Amyloidosis Canada (TAC)
national.description: Patient and family support network for transthyretin amyloidosis

national.name: Canadian Amyloidosis Nursing Network (CANN)
national.description: National network for connecting amyloidosis nurses
